questions.question_text: A user notices a crushing sound coming from a multifunction printer. The user investigates and notices several pages printed off center, and some of the pages did not print. A technician arrives to troubleshoot and notices the MFP has several warnings. Which of the following steps should the technician take to resolve the issues? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: this is simple, you would clean the transfer drum and replace the toner.

comments.content: Im not that good with printer problems but the answer states that "delete all printer jobs" wouldn't it be better just to stop the print jobs rather than delete all of it? since "stopping print jobs" is not in the choices, A and F would be the best answers by default?

discussion.content:
The rollers are defective since its not feeding all the paper to print. However I would clear all print jobs. how would you diagnose your problem. than clear the paper jam, things feed on a jam and make things crooked or just feed irregularly until there is a jam.

Its a bad question without enough info.

comments.content:
If you look up Paper Jams in google, most sites say that If you are having a Jam things to do would, to turn off the printer, clear the jam, then clean the rollers
Source: https://www.capital-solutions.co.uk/paper-jams-causes-solutions-and-prevention/

questions.question_text: An inkjet printer shows a print-head quality problem. The user replaces the print head, and then the printer is online and indicates no errors. Users then report text documents print fine, but color charts are not correct. Which of the following should be checked FIRST?

discussion.content: Yes the answer is C

Print head alignment corrects the installation positions of the print head and improves ***deviated colors*** and lines.
I would go with C.
this one was on my exam, i choose A, but i failed my exam, i don't know if its the right answer
If alignment is off you would not get any color. And if ink does transfer with imperfect connections expect to make a mess inside your printer staining things.
Can anyone explain this please? If alignment was off, wouldn't that affect text aswell?

comments.content: If the alignment is off, the color mix won't be quite accurate. e.g., Greens would have a little yellow on 1 side & blue on the other because they aren't hitting the same spot.

discussion.content: Should be A.

choices.A: The color ink cartridges are from the printer manufacturer
choices.B: The print quality is set to best
choices.D: Print drivers are up to date
choices.C: The print head alignment check passes

questions.question_text:
A user reports that printing on heavy cardstock paper results in the image smearing if touched. When printing on plain paper, the problem does not occur.
Which of the following would be the NEXT troubleshooting step to perform?

discussion.content: The fuser temperature and paper feed speed settings are adjusted by the printer when you change the paper type in the printer settings. In the real world you would tell the end user to select card stock / thick paper in the printer paper settings menu and the laser printer would automatically optimize its settings for this paper type by increasing the fuser temperature. In an office setting, on leased commercial laser printers, most settings are locked out so people don't screw up the printer. Manually changing the fuser temp, typically, would only be available on a home laser printer where you have full control over the printer menu options.

according to some info an hp site, the fuser temps are increased and the feed rate is slowed. 
https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/LaserJet-Printing/How-does-choosing-a-different-quot-media-type-quot-affect/td-p/6654693

HOWEVER, I don't think the temp should/would be increased because that might cause burning/browning/discoloration of the paper, whereas simply lowering the feed rate of the paper will allow it more time for the heat (which is known to be a non-paper-burning temperature) to fully penetrate the paper and toner.. That being said, I cannot find ANYTHING in any of the official CompTIA literature that mentions what do do here. 

Furthermore, the only way to change these sorts of settings is to tell the printer its printing on card stock and let it figure the rest out itself.
Thanks had no idea what the heck The Fuser temperature was.

Laser Printers will pass the standard paper through rollers in the fuser assembly, where temperatures can go up to 801 degrees Fahrenheit. If you were to attempt to print with a thicker printer, the heat would not transfer as easily which will result in the images smearing.
Thanks for the clarification!
so the correct answer is A increasing the fuser temperature will fix the problem

choices.D: The fuser assembly is not reaching the correct temperature
choices.C: The corona wire is defective and needs to be replaced
choices.A: The paper in the trays has been exposed to moist air
choices.B: The toner cartridge contains old toner

questions.question_text: Users of an older laser printer notice the printing on output is easily scratched off the paper. Which of the following is the MOST likely root cause?

discussion.content: Laser printer = easily scratched off = fuser problem

choices.A: Update the drivers on the workstation

questions.question_text: A technician set up a shared printer on the company network for company users to print. The technician also set up a user to print from outside the company through the native cloud printing software. The technician ensures the network is set up to pass the traffic without error. However, when printing a test page, the user received the following error message: Printer unavailable. Which of the following should the technician do to stop the error message?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: E
The answer is Remote Print, the user is trying to do a remote connection. Therefore you to make certain it's enabled.

Selected Answer: E
The answer is Remote Print, the user is trying to do a remote connection. Therefore you to make certain it's enabled.

I don't believe it's a driver issue. Without the correct driver, the printer would not even show up, then you would not have the ability to even try to print a test page. I agree with Momo by elimination.

Selected Answer: D
I believe it is D
Enable remote print by elimination
